After that, it is just a matter of getting the CLI to recognize/tolerate/default to the new alias.

Package (and action summaries) are not working correctly in the go cli (another test gap):

```
openwhisk> wsk package update p -a parameters '[ {"name":"someP", "required":false}, {"name":"anotherP", "required":false} ]'
ok: updated package p
openwhisk> ./bin/go-cli/wsk -i --apihost 192.168.99.100 package get p --summary
package /guest/p
openwhisk> wsk package get p --summary
package /guest/p
   (params: someP anotherP)
```

note that in the python cli, the words `package` and `params` are formatted in bold text.

PPG 952.

Disabling the connection tests for now until we can reproduce 😕

@rabbah - You are correct in that that doing `go-cli/wsk --apihost <valid host> property get --apibuild` will not behave like the Python API.

The hard Go CLI limitation is support for argument overloading - assigning the same named argument to the root command and also to a sub-command.  In this example, not only is the argument assigned twice, but it has different characteristics.  The `--apihost` argument assigned to the `wsk` root command takes a value while the `--apihost` argument assigned to the `property get` command does not.  The Go CLI argument package permits the assignment of the same argument name to different sub-commands as well as the root command; however, for any particular CLI invocation, all arguments are merged such that the argument is applied only to the last sub-command.

If we want the `wsk property get` command to take a apihost argument as the target host, the argument label will need to change.  That said, I think the better solution may be to separate the existing `wsk property` command into two commands - one for configuring the CLI and another for accessing whisk server values.  This would remove the `--apihost` argument overload conflict.

See also PR #924 comment https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/924#issuecomment-234981580

I think this is a great idea, and I would like to see it generalized to include rules. Now that I have several rules in place, activations from several rules are interleaved. This makes it difficult to determine the "thread" of activations - which is really an important key to debugging. 

Some kind of activation metadata (like a new id) that ties multiple activations together would not only allow users to more effectively debug logs, but would also allow clients like the CLI or Bluemix UI to present activation records in a grouped or threaded fashion that would make it clear to the user the chain of events to which the activations belong.

Activations have a `caused` property which was introduced for this reason. We lost this causality tracking when we rewrote the activator but we will be adding it back (for rules). And with the new sequence implementation, we will have this feature. @nauerz-ibm timely issue.

@ioana-blue will create an issue for the new sequences work.

Timely issue. I'm changing our implementation of sequences and as a consequence, we'll have activation ids for sequences. More details about the implementation are discussed in #995

Additional benefit:  The monitoring service does not have to fetch a huge volume of data repeatedly which probably is also hurting consul currently.  Since the controller will reflect its view of concurrent activity, this can be used by the UI directly and we can avoid logic getting out-of-sync.

If we do this, I think it should proceed in 3 phases:
1.  **This first step should immediately make things better.**  Decrease the frequency of consul updates by the invoker so we have some breathing room.  Since we don't want extra connection and also don't want health updates to be slower, we can simply do the per user count writes on every other iteration of consul posting while doing health updates on every iteration. 
2. **This creates the appropriate abstraction for the monitoring service.**  Have the controller put into consul its view of concurrent activity.  The monitoring service should look only at these values and not at the old controller values and not anything from the invoker.
3. **Intermediate step to confirm that adding 2 extra (small) fields will not impact performance**  Extend the active ack with the additional fields as outlined in "New idea" above.
4. **Cutover to new logic and decrease consul traffic**  Change the controller to use active ack and maintain the new maps and no longer poll consul for invoker information.   Delete the posting of per counts by the invokers.

For clarity regarding the format of the key string and value string, let's consider both of these valuea for the command `wsk action create test test.js -a k1 v1`
1. k1, the key.  This will eventually be folded into JSON prior to the REST endpoint call.  Currently, the user is not expected to provide k1 in valid JSON format, and the CLI will handle the conversion of the k1 string into a valid JSON string.  Conversion involves escaping embedded `/` and `"` characters, wrapping the entire value in double quotes.
2. v1, the value.  Stephen's comment above implies that this value must be a correctly formatted JSON object, array, string, number, `true`, `false`, or `null`.  The CLI should NOT perform any conversion of this value as it is expected to be valid JSON.  This value will NOT be wrapped in double quotes when folding it into the JSON body that's sent to the server.  That said, we need to be clear about the format of a JSON string which, according to the standard, must be double quoted (quotes must be included in the argument passed to the CLI from the shell) and appropriately escaped.

Note: CLI users must still provide appropriate escaping of the k1 and v1 values to ensure the shell's argument parsing does not corrupt the intended value.

http://www.json.org/

yes,I am considering filing a bug now #1002

> @csantanapr is it still possible to run the openwhisk vagrant machine without mounting a shared folder?

The use case was not very useful and was bring a lot of confusing on having too many ways to setup, and tend to let people just workaround root cause problems.

We should not be using "ln" anywhere to have a chance to support windows natively, there are lot of developer that only have Windows as their dev workstation.

This `tools/go-cli/build.gradle` is incompatible with Windows by using "ln"
https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/tools/go-cli/build.gradle#L32

```
   String link_to_path = new File("${projectDir}/../../bin/go-cli/wsk").getCanonicalPath()
    String link_from_path = new File("${projectDir}/../../bin/go-cli/${go_osname}/${go_osarch}/wsk").getCanonicalPath()
    exec {
        executable "ln"
        args "-s", "${link_from_path}", "${link_to_path}"
    }
```

The strange thing is that we already inside the VM in vagrant and it work
https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/tools/vagrant/Vagrantfile#L134

```
  rm -r bin/wsk && rm -r bin/wskadmin
  (cd bin && sudo ln -s ../tools/cli/wsk wsk)
  (cd bin && sudo ln -s ../tools/cli/wskadmin wskadmin)
```

I guess if we use `sudo` it might work, the problem is that would cause problems, like mac trying to run with `sudo`

I think the quick fix is to just do a copy of the binary (using gradle ) , instead of `ln`

```
task copyTask(type: Copy) {
    from '${link_from_path}'
    into '${link_to_path}'
}
```

More elegant solution would be to write wrapper scripts wsk (bash) and wsk.bat, for the bash it will detect if linux or mac, and the arch, for windows will detect the arch and then delegate to the correct binary on the fly.

@mdeuser can you take this one since you are the one that has a Windows box and can test the propose fix with copyTask?
Why you think you have not hit this problem on your Windows workstation? maybe you created the symlink manually, and it's seating there making any subsequent calls to `ln` to be ignore/success
